questions.text: A physician working in a tropical country observes a high prevalence of bacillary dysentery among patients presenting with acute gastroenteritis. Stool cultures often isolate a particular species of Shigella. Which species of Shigella is most commonly isolated in cases of bacillary dysentery in tropical countries like India?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Shigella flexneri.

 

Option B:

 

Shigella flexneri is the most common cause of bacillary dysentery in developing countries, including those with tropical climates like India. It is responsible for a significant burden of disease in these regions due to factors like overcrowding and poor sanitation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Shigella dysenteriae - While this species can cause outbreaks, it is not the most commonly isolated species in tropical countries.

 

Option C. Shigella sonnei - This species is more commonly associated with developed countries.

 

Option D. Shigella boydii - This species is less common and is not typically the predominant cause of bacillary dysentery in tropical countries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p306, 2/e p318, Ananthanarayan 9th/p 288, 10/e p291

questions.text: A 20-year-old male has been diagnosed with typhoid fever. His physician is considering antibiotic therapy and is aware that while many antibiotics can be used to treat this condition, some are not recommended. Which of the following antibiotics is generally not used in the treatment of typhoid fever?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Amikacin.

 

Option A:

 

Amikacin, an aminoglycoside antibiotic, is not typically used in the treatment of typhoid fever. This is because Salmonella typhi, the causative agent of typhoid fever, is intracellular, and aminoglycosides have poor intracellular penetration.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Cefixime - This is a third-generation cephalosporin that is often used orally for the treatment of typhoid fever, especially in areas where there is resistance to fluoroquinolones.

 

Option C. Ciprofloxacin - A fluoroquinolone that is commonly used for the treatment of typhoid fever, although resistance has been increasing.

 

Option D. Azithromycin - It is used for the treatment of typhoid fever, particularly in areas with known fluoroquinolone resistance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amikacin is not commonly used for the treatment of typhoid fever due to its poor intracellular penetration, which is essential for treating an intracellular pathogen like Salmonella typhi. It is typically treated with antibiotics like cefixime, ciprofloxacin, and azithromycin.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med. Microbiology 2/e p338

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy with a known history of sickle cell anemia presents to the pediatric clinic with pain in his legs. Radiographic findings are suggestive of osteomyelitis, but there is no evidence of pus formation. Given his underlying condition, which organism is most likely responsible for causing his osteomyelitis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Salmonella species.

 

Option A:

 

Patients with sickle cell anemia are at increased risk for osteomyelitis due to Salmonella species, likely related to microvascular infarctions in the bone leading to a compromised blood supply, which provides an environment conducive to infection with this organism.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Staphylococcus aureus - While this is the most common cause of osteomyelitis overall, Salmonella species are more specifically associated with osteomyelitis in patients with sickle cell anemia.

 

Option C. Haemophilus influenzae - This organism is not typically associated with osteomyelitis in patients with sickle cell disease.

 

Option D. Enterobacter species - These are less common causes of osteomyelitis and are not specifically associated with sickle cell anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Salmonella species are a common cause of osteomyelitis in patients with sickle cell anemia, particularly when there is no evidence of suppurative infection.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med.Microbiology, 2/e,p340

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents to the emergency department with facial flushing, rash, and palpitations 30 minutes after consuming a fish dish at a local restaurant. He also complains of a peppery taste in his mouth while eating. His vital signs are stable, and he has no significant medical history. Which gram-negative bacteria, often associated with improperly stored fish, is most likely responsible for his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Morganella species

 

Option D:

 

The patient's symptoms are suggestive of scombroid fish poisoning, which is not an infection but a form of food poisoning that occurs due to the ingestion of fish that has not been properly refrigerated. This allows the growth of certain bacteria, including gram-negative Proteus species, which produce histidine decarboxylase. This enzyme converts histidine in the fish to histamine, leading to symptoms resembling an allergic reaction.

 

The organism morganella morganii , present under the proteae tribe is the one that causes Scromboid fish poisoning. 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Staphylococcus aureus: This is a gram-positive bacterium, not gram-negative. It is commonly associated with food poisoning, particularly in foods like dairy products, meat, and sandwiches, but not typically with fish. The symptoms include nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea, which are different from the symptoms presented by the patient.

 

Option B. Shigella species: These are gram-negative bacteria, but they are primarily associated with waterborne outbreaks and not with fish. Shigella typically causes symptoms like diarrhea (often bloody), fever, and stomach cramps, which are not in line with the symptoms described by the patient.

 

Option C. Salmonella species: While these are gram-negative bacteria and can be associated with foodborne illnesses, they are more commonly linked to poultry, eggs, and meat rather than fish. The symptoms of Salmonella infection include diarrhea, fever, and abdominal cramps, different from the symptoms the patient is experiencing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MORGANELLA  species as a gram-negative bacterium that can release histamine when it inhabits improperly stored fish, leading to scombroid poisoning.

 

Ref: Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p311, 2/e p323

questions.text: A microbiology lab is testing bacterial isolates from a patient with a suspected Shigella infection. One isolate is noted to ferment lactose slowly, with a positive result only after 48 hours of incubation. Which species of Shigella is known to exhibit this late lactose fermenting characteristic?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) S. sonnei.

 

Option A:

 

S. sonnei is known for its ability to ferment lactose, but unlike typical lactose-fermenting bacteria that do so within 24 hours, it ferments lactose slowly and may only show a positive result after 48 hours, which is termed "late lactose fermentation."

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. S. flexneri - This species does not ferment lactose, or it does so very weakly and is not known for late lactose fermentation.

 

Option C. S. boydii - Similar to S. flexneri, it does not typically ferment lactose.

 

Option D. S. dysenteriae - This species is a non-lactose fermenter and is known for more severe disease presentations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p305, 2/e p317

questions.text: During a lecture on infectious diseases, a professor discusses the epidemiology of typhoid fever. She emphasizes the importance of the infective dose in the transmission of the disease. What is the typical infective dose required for Salmonella typhi to cause typhoid fever in a susceptible individual?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 102-105 bacilli

 

Option C:

 

The infective dose for Salmonella typhi is relatively low, and ingesting as few as 102-105  organisms can cause typhoid fever in a susceptible individual. This low infective dose is a factor in the spread of typhoid fever, particularly in areas with poor sanitation where small amounts of contaminated food or water can cause infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The infective dose of Salmonella typhi, the causative agent of typhoid fever, ranges from 102-105  organisms.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p319, 2/e p332, Harrison Principles of Internal Medicine19/e p1049-53, 20/e p1174

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presents with a high-grade fever, marked splenomegaly, and leukopenia. Despite aggressive treatment, she deteriorates rapidly and succumbs to her illness within days. Autopsy reveals the presence of longitudinal ulcers in the intestine. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Typhoid fever.

 

Option A:

 

Typhoid fever, caused by Salmonella typhi, can lead to characteristic longitudinal ulcers along the small intestine, particularly in the ileum. In severe cases, it can cause complications such as intestinal hemorrhage or perforation, which can be fatal. The presentation of fever, splenomegaly, and leukopenia, along with the rapid clinical decline and autopsy findings, are consistent with typhoid fever.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Tuberculosis - Intestinal tuberculosis could cause similar symptoms, but the rapid course of illness and the specific autopsy findings make typhoid fever more likely.

 

Option C. Amebiasis - Amebiasis can cause ulcers in the intestine, but they are typically flask-shaped and would not typically lead to such a rapid decline.

 

Option D. Crohn's disease - This chronic inflammatory bowel disease can cause longitudinal ulcers but would not typically result in a rapid clinical deterioration leading to death.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diagnose typhoid fever based on clinical features of fever, splenomegaly, leukopenia, and autopsy findings of longitudinal ulcers in the intestine, along with a rapidly fatal course.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p310, 2/e p333, 19/e p1049-53, Harrison Principles of Internal Medicine20/e p1175

questions.text: 35-year-old male presents to the clinic with symptoms of gastroenteritis. He reports that he started experiencing abdominal pain, diarrhea, and mild fever after attending a local seafood festival. A stool culture on differential media shows the presence of a gram-negative, rod-shaped bacterium that produces hydrogen sulfide. Which of the following Salmonella species is the patient most likely infected with?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) S. Typhimurium.

 

Option A:

 

S. Typhimurium  is a non-typhoidal salmonella and is known to produce hydrogen sulfide (H2S), which can be detected on differential media such as Hektoen enteric agar where it produces black colonies due to H2S production. This bacterium is a common cause of gastroenteritis and can be contracted from various food sources, making it a likely culprit in a patient with post-food festival gastroenteritis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. S. Typhi: While this is a hydrogen sulfide-producing species, it is typically associated with a more systemic illness known as typhoid fever (Enteric fever), rather than gastroenteritis.

 

Option C. S. Paratyphi A and d) S. Paratyphi B: These species also cause enteric fevers similar to S. Typhi and are not commonly associated with the symptoms described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

S. Typhimurium as a hydrogen sulfide-producing Salmonella species commonly associated with gastroenteritis.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastrys Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/ep321, 2/e p336

questions.text: A local public health department is investigating a recent outbreak of enteric fever. They have identified a single water source as the outbreak point. The department decides to administer a vaccine to the susceptible population. Which of the following vaccination schedules is most appropriate for the oral live-attenuated typhoid vaccine (Vivotif)?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Day 1, Day 3, Day 5, Day 7

 

Option A:

 

Typhoral (oral live attenuated S. Typhi Ty21a vaccine):  

 

  • Typhoral is a stable live attenuated mutant of S. Typhi strain Ty21a, which lacks the enzyme UDP-galactose-4-epimerase (Gal E mutant)
  • On ingestion, it multiplies for some time, initiates the immune response but self-destructs (dies of its own after 4–5 cell divisions, due to lack of Gal E enzyme) and therefore cannot induce any pathogenesis
  • It is indicated only after 6 years of age
  • The vaccine is available in lyophilized form as enteric coated capsules
  • It is given orally before food, on alternate days- 1, 3, 5, 7. No antibiotics should be given during this period
  • Revaccination is recommended every 5 years with a full 4-dose series
  • Protective immunity starts after 7 days of the last dose and lasts for 4 years.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Typhoral is an oral vaccine for typhoid fever, comprising a live attenuated S. Typhi strain Ty21a, lacking UDP-galactose-4-epimerase (Gal E). Recommended for individuals aged 6 and above. 

 

Typhoral is administered orally in a lyophilized, enteric-coated capsule form on days 1, 3, 5, and 7 (revaccination every 5 years). 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p326, 2/e p339, Ananthanarayan 9/e p295-96
